introduction.p: The graph of a quadratic function f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c is called a parabolaparabola. Some parabolas are shown in .

All these parabolas share certain features. The graph has either a highest point (if the parabola opens downward, as in a) or a lowest point (if the parabola opens upward, as in b). This high or low point is called the vertexvertex of the graph.

The parabola is symmetric about a vertical line, called the axis of symmetryaxis of symmetry, that runs through the vertex. The y-intercept is the point where the parabola intersects the y-axis. The graph of a quadratic function always has exactly one y-interceptintercept.

However, the graph may cross the x-axis at one point, at two points, or not at all. Points where the parabola intersects the x-axis are called the x-intercepts. If there are two x-intercepts, they are equidistant from the axis of symmetry.
The values of the constants a, b, and c determine the location and orientation of the parabola. We will begin by considering each of these constants separately.

assemblage.title: Vertex Form
assemblage.p: When a quadratic function is written in the form y=a(x-h)^2+k we say that the quadratic is written in vertex form. Once written in this form, the vertex of the parabola is the point (h,k) and the axis of symmetry is the line x=h .

warning.p: Notice in the definition given above, the vertex of the parabola is (\alert{h},k) and yet in the formula we have -h showing up y=a(x\alert{-h})^2+k. If, for example we have a parabola written as y=2(x+4)^2-3 then the vertex is not (4,-3), but rather it is (-4,-3) as we would have to rewrite it as 2(x+4)^2-3=2(x-(-4))^2-3 in order to have the parabola written in vertex form.

subsection.title: Finding the Vertex
subsection.p:
The process we will use to put a quadratic into vertex form is through a process called completing the square. Given a quadratic function in the form f(x)=x^2+bx, to complete the square we simply
divide b by 2 and square the outcome, to get (\dfrac{b}{2})^2
then add zero to the function by adding and subtracting this number f(x)=x^2+bx=(x^2+bx+(\dfrac{b}{2})^2)-(\dfrac{b}{2})^2
we have then completed the square in that we may write \begin{align*} f(x)=x^2+bx \amp =\alert{(x^2+bx+(\dfrac{b}{2})^2)}-(\dfrac{b}{2})^2\\ \amp = \alert{(x+\dfrac{b}{2})^2}-(\dfrac{b}{2})^2 \end{align*}
The best way to learn this is through examples, so let's work through one together.

statement.p: Put the quadratic y=2x^2 - 6x - 5 into vertex form.

li.p: Start by factoring out the coefficient of the term x^2, but do not factor it out of the constant term: 2x^2 - 6x - 5=2\cdot(\alert{x^2 - 3x}) -5. Now, rewrite the expression within the parenthesis with the constant on the right side. 2\cdot(\alert{x^2 - 3x} ~ )-5

Complete the square within the parenthesis p = \frac{1}{2}(-3) = \frac{-3}{2} ~~~\text{ and } ~~~ p^2 = \left(\frac{-3}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{9}{4} Add and subtract \frac{9}{4}: 2\cdot (x^2 - 3x \alert{+\frac{9}{4}}) \alert{-2\cdot\frac{9}{4}}. Note that I had to subtract 2\cdot\frac{9}{4} as the part that we added within the parenthesis was being multiplied by the constant 2 seen on the far left of the equation.
Rewrite as the square of a binomial 2\cdot \left(x - \frac{3}{2}\right)^2 -5-2\cdot\frac{9}{4}.
Simplify to get the function in vertex form y=2\cdot \left(x - \frac{3}{2}\right)^2 -\frac{19}{2}.

subsection.title: The Graph of y = ax^2 + bx + c
subsection.p: Consider the function y = 2x^2 + 8x + 6. If we put this quadratic into vertex form we get the equation y=2\cdot (x+2)^2-2. From the vertex form we read off the vertex to be (-2,-2) with axis of symmetry along the line x=-2.

We find the x-intercepts of the graph by setting y equal to zero. For this, it is easier to go back to the function as written in standard form: \begin{align*} 0 \amp= 2x^2 + 8x + 6\amp\amp\text{Factor the right side.}\\ \amp= 2(x + 1)(x + 3)\amp\amp\text{Set each factor equal to zero.}\\ x + 1 \amp=0 ~~~\text{ or } ~~~x + 3 = 0\\ x\amp= -1 \hphantom{blankbl} x = -3 \end{align*} The x-intercepts are the points (-1, 0) and (-3, 0).

sidebyside.p: The y-intercept of the graph is found by setting x equal to zero: y = 2(\alert{0})2 + 8(\alert{0}) + 6 = 6 You can see that the y-coordinate of the y-intercept, (0,6), is just the constant term of the quadratic equation. The completed graph is shown in .

subsection.title: Sketching a Parabola
subsection.p: Once we have located the vertex of the parabola, the x-intercepts, and the y-intercept, we can sketch a reasonably accurate graph. Recall that the graph should be symmetric about a vertical line through the vertex. We summarize the procedure as follows.

statement.p: Sketch a graph of the equation y = x^2 + 3x + 1, showing the significant points.

solution.p:
We follow the steps outlined above.
Because a = 1 \gt 0, we know that the parabola opens upward.
Compute the coordinates of the vertex: \begin{aligned} x_v\amp=\frac{-b}{2a}=\frac{-3}{2(1)}= -1.5\\ y_v\amp= (-1.5)2 + 3(-1.5) + 1 = -1.25 \end{aligned}
The vertex is the point (-1.5,-1.25).
Set y equal to zero to find the x-intercepts. \begin{aligned} 0 \amp= x^2 + 3x + 1\amp\amp\text{Use the quadratic formula.}\\ x \amp=\frac{-3\pm\sqrt{3^2-4(1)(1)}}{2(1)}\\ \amp=\frac{-3\pm\sqrt{5}}{2} \end{aligned}
Rounding to the nearest tenth, we find that the x-intercepts are approximately (-2.6, 0) and (-0.4, 0).
Substitute x = 0 to find the y-intercept, (0, 1).
The axis of symmetry is the vertical line x = -1.5, so the y-intercept lies 1.5 units to the right of the axis of symmetry.
There must be another point on the parabola with the same y-coordinate as the y-intercept but 1.5 units to the left of the axis of symmetry. The coordinates of this point are (-3, 1).
Finally, plot the x-intercepts, the vertex, and the y-intercept and its symmetric point, and draw a parabola through them. The finished graph is shown in . parabola
